title: Chair, "KC 1", Designed 1996, produced 2008
medium: Rope (aramid fibers over carbon core; macramé knotting technique), soaked in epoxy resin, dried
description: Rigid, epoxy-impregnated, light green one-piece form composed of aramid fiber rope criss-crossed and knotted into the shape of a low four-legged chair.
justification:
From Acquistion justification:
Context:Marcel Wanders is a young veteran of contemporary Dutch design.&nbsp; He is a member of the Dutch cooperative Droog (Dry) Design, sharing their vision for simplicity and occasional wit, creating visually spare and modest designs.&nbsp; His early works are distinguished by their use of ordinary materials or things---string, sponges, eggs, lamp shades---employed in new and often surprisingly delightful ways.&nbsp; Because of this, many of Wanders designs have the look of familiarity, like his "Knotted Chair" that evokes a time-worn hammock, but with a contemporary sensibility.
The object:The chair is of rope "made from braided aramid fibers wrapped around a carbon core, knotted into the shape of a chair. It is then impregnated with epoxy and hung on a frame to harden."&nbsp; Like many Droog designs, "Knotted Chair" is a craft-based approach to new materials, synthesizing ancient techniques, in this case, macramé, with high-tech fibers to yield a new furniture form.
Although originally part of the Droog collection, "Knotted Chair" is now distributed by the Italian manufacturer Cappellini.&nbsp; It was an outgrowth of a collaboration between the Droog Design Foundation and the Laboratory for Structures and Materials at the Faculty of Aviation and Aerospace of the University of Technology in Delft.&nbsp; The result was a new durable chair design that achieves lightness and delicacy, both physically and visually.

tombstone.epitaph: Chair, "KC 1", Designed 1996, produced 2008. Rope (aramid fibers over carbon core; macramé knotting technique), soaked in epoxy resin, dried. Gift of Cappellini. 2008-23-1.
